author: ratz
title: blue collar workers, unite!
review:
personally i have never seen a similar vehicle in real life, do or did they actually exist?
the set seems to be a direct predecessor to set 6532, which came out 8 years later and looks quite similar, a bit less sturdy perhaps. the focus here concentrates on playability rather than on a sleek design, you can't lose the trailer, and the tipper is safely attached.

author: legotowner
title: I was too rough
review: I was too young too when I got this set, one my first I couldnt even build it, it was too hard at that age. When I was ready to make it I had already snapped the black piece that made the tipper worker and the bucket itself had a large crack. I was pretty dissapointed as this set would have served a great purpose and been a good worker.

author: T79
title: Big (relatively) Monster
review:
Another set I remember having since I was very young. Also another set I have practically never rebuilt as I had lost the instructions before I could really build something myself. Are we noticing a pattern here?

Parts

The main part here of course is the bucket itself, which for small hands is satisfyingly big. Other interesting parts are the two different hinges: one for connecting the cab with the trailer and the other for lifting the bucket, for a long time these were my only ones of these (at least in black), the bucket is still unique in my collection.

Minifigures

One worker in hard hat and the favourite blue shirt with white pocket print, again generic enough to be used in whatever role required. Together with the worker from #6302 and the garage owner from #361 (with the addition of a hard hat) this one formed my construction crew for a long time.

The build

Nice and short, I like the alternating black and yellow lines on the cab front but it all really is just a big bucket on big hinges on big wheels (relatively speaking, back then they were big... and it still is a small model).

The completed model

On the same scale #6624 and this one seem to be opposites: both have ~40 pieces but while #6624 is small and cute this one is a big, lumbering beast nearly double the size. Again, just as with #6624, something to actually dump would have been nice too but this can be found easily enough. :-)

Overall opinion

Forget what I said with my review of #6624, quantity has a quality all of its own! My children love both but this one gets to do the heavy work: negating crater plates and hauling big loads (singing the title song of 'Bob the Builder' is entirely optional).
